display_asset.caption: A Palestinian man wounded when ordnance exploded in Gaza on Thursday as residents cleared rubble from the war with Israel last summer.

summaries.body: Four Palestinians were killed and more than 40 were wounded after ordnance exploded in Gaza as residents cleared rubble from the war with Israel last summer.
An Afghan National Army helicopter crashed in southern Afghanistan on Thursday, killing all 17 people aboard, government officials said.

display_asset.credit: Charlotte Police Department, via Associated Press

summaries.body: A police dashboard camera video from the shooting death of a black man in North Carolina in 2013 has been made public in the trial of the officer accused of killing him.
When a Kentucky sheriff posted a flier on Facebook asking local drug dealers to snitch, there was skepticism. But then they caught a drug dealer.
A European Space Observatory telescope captured a striking image of the so-called Southern Owl Nebula, a gigantic glowing bubble that is a gas cloud formed from a dying star.

posts.footer: The Times reporter was referring to the violin restored to the family of Roman Totenberg, the violin virtuoso. Twitter

summaries.body: The Totenberg sisters were just reunited with the Stradivarius that was stolen from their father in 1980 http://t.co/v3y9FVn9yz

display_asset.caption: The champion free diver Natalia Molchanova, pictured in June 2014, has been missing since Sunday; Spain’s Civil Guard said it would continue surface searches through the coming weekend.

summaries.body: The champion free diver Natalia Molchanova was teaching inexperienced divers when she failed to surface from a dive off the coast of Spain on Sunday, her son said.
A suicide bomber has killed 13 people and wounded nine during noon prayers at a mosque in Saudi Arabia, the authorities said, the latest such attack in the country.
At least 169 people have died in Pakistan in the past month after monsoon rains set off floods in more than 2,400 villages, the authorities said.
Australia has turned around over 600 asylum seekers on 20 separate boats since enacting new border controls in late 2013, Peter Dutton, the immigration minister, said.
London commuters are dealing with long lines and delays as they try to navigate the capital during a strike that has shut down the Tube network.

display_asset.caption: Charles Goldstein at his office in Manhattan in 1985.
display_asset.credit: Chester Higgins Jr./The New York Times

summaries.body: Charles Goldstein, a high-powered New York real estate lawyer who died last week at 78, was a tenacious advocate for recovering art stolen from Holocaust victims.
Officials in Alabama cleared Blue Bell to resume production at its plant there, months after the ice cream maker issued a nationwide recall over listeria concerns.
A Labor Party youth camp on the Norwegian island of Utoya will reopen this weekend, four years after a gunman killed dozens of people there.
Rescuers saved 400 people, but at least 25 died when an overcrowded fishing boat carrying migrants to Europe capsized off the coast of Libya, officials said.
A former campaign manager for Ron Paul, Jesse Benton, has been indicted on campaign finance charges from 2012.

display_asset.caption: Anjem Choudary, center, at a protest outside the American Embassy in London in 2011 after the killing of Osama bin Laden.

summaries.body: British authorities charged the radical preacher Anjem Choudary, some of whose followers have joined the Islamic State, with inciting support for the organization.
Shares in Comcast, Time Warner, 21st Century Fox, CBS, Viacom, Discovery and AMC Networks all were down, with some plunging by as much as 12 percent in midday trading.
Microsoft said it would offer new parents an additional eight weeks of paid time off from their jobs at the company, a day after Netflix announced its new parental leave policy.

display_asset.caption: A monument under construction last month along the new channel of the Suez Canal at the port city of Ismailia.

summaries.body: President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt is promoting a new Suez Canal channel as a historic victory. But economists say it is unlikely to significantly transform the passage.

display_asset.caption: The small Graava camera has a G.P.S. chip and an accelerometer, sensors that detect location and acceleration force during any video recording.

summaries.body: Graava, a new start-up, plans to announce an action camera that works with an online service to automatically edit footage into videos of only the most dramatic moments.

display_asset.caption: Katie Ledecky, left, won gold in the 200-meter freestyle at the world swimming championships Wednesday, and the defending champion, Missy Franklin, won bronze.

summaries.body: Katie Ledecky, an American swimmer, won the 200-meter freestyle at the world championships against a stellar field that included the defending champion, Missy Franklin.

display_asset.caption: Migrants waited last week outside the entrance to the tunnel underneath the English Channel in Calais, France.
display_asset.credit: Tom Jamieson for The New York Times

summaries.body: Katrin Bennhold, a reporter for The New York Times based in London, answered readers’ questions about the migrant crisis in Calais, France.
The White House has ended its ban on photography during public tours, so a Times politics reporter, Nicholas Corasaniti, went on a visit. Follow him on Snapchat.
Amid tight security, China’s Catholics have ordained their first new bishop in three years, signaling a possible thawing in tension between the Vatican and Beijing.
The trial in Zimbabwe of a professional hunter who helped an American kill a popular lion named Cecil in an allegedly illegal hunt was postponed to Sept. 28.
Pope Francis urged pastors to avoid treating divorced Roman Catholics who remarry as if they were excommunicated, saying they deserve better treatment from the church.
The Turkish foreign minister said American drones and planes were arriving at a base close to the border with Syria, in preparation for a campaign against the Islamic State.
Police forces in five jurisdictions have confirmed that they received allegations of child sexual abuse involving Edward Heath, a former prime minister.

display_asset.caption: Cilla Black during a 1966 recording session for the song ‘Alfie.’

summaries.body: Cilla Black, who met the Beatles while checking coats in a Liverpool nightclub and became Britain's top-selling female singer of the 1960s, died at 72.
The widow of a former South Korean president began a visit to North Korea, saying she hoped it would lead to more dialogue. South Korea has said the trip is strictly personal.
Kellogg, the world's biggest maker of breakfast cereals, said it would try to stop using artificial colors and flavors in its cereals and snack bars by the end of 2018.

display_asset.caption: Julius Malema arriving in court in Polokwane, South Africa, on Monday. The corruption charges against Mr. Malema, a critic of President Jacob G. Zuma, the leader of an opposition party, were thrown out on Tuesday.

summaries.body: A South African court dismissed a long-running corruption case against the opposition leader Julius Malema, handing a victory to one of the president's most strident critics.
Russia formally staked a claim to a vast area of the Arctic Ocean, including the North Pole. The U.N. rejected a similar claim in 2002.

display_asset.caption: Theo Bronkhorst, right, and his lawyer Givemore Muvhiringi after a court appearance in Hwange, Zimbabwe, last week.

summaries.body: Theo Bronkhorst, right, the guide who led the hunt that killed Cecil the lion in Zimbabwe, said he did nothing wrong. He is scheduled to stand trial on Wednesday.
The number of new Ebola diagnoses in Sierra Leone and Guinea reached its lowest point in well over a year last week, the United Nations said.
Netflix said it would allow employees up to one year of maternity or paternity leave after a child's birth or adoption.
A Port Authority police officer, above, delivered a baby on a PATH concourse at the new World Trade Center. The baby was healthy and in stable condition.

display_asset.caption: “The Avengers: Age of Ultron” helped drive profit at the Walt Disney Company last quarter with $1.4 billion in global ticket sales.

summaries.body: “The Avengers” helped lift profit at the Walt Disney Company 11 percent in the most recent quarter, to $2.48 billion, beating Wall Street’s expectations.
The mother of Sandra Bland, the Illinois woman who died in a Texas jail cell in July, filed a federal lawsuit that faulted jail guards and the trooper who arrested Ms. Bland.

display_asset.caption: Darren Wilson in a photograph released as evidence by the St. Louis County prosecutor's office in  November.

summaries.body: Darren Wilson spoke about his life, race and police work in an interview published almost a year after he fatally shot Michael Brown, an unarmed black teenager, in Ferguson.

display_asset.caption: HitchBOT sat near the harbor waiting for a ride last month in Marblehead, Mass..

summaries.body: A hitchhiking robot that safely made it through three countries was destroyed in Philadelphia. It was in the early days of what was supposed to be an American tour.
Pakistani and Indian border guards traded gunfire and mortar shells along the disputed border in the Himalayan region of Kashmir, killing two Pakistanis and an Indian.
Britain will extend its air campaign against ISIS in Iraq by a year, using Tornado fighter jets there until at least early 2017, Defense Secretary Michael Fallon said.
Moscow has responded to Sweden's expulsion of a Russian diplomat by forcing a Swedish representative to leave the country, amid higher tensions in the region.
An investigation in Germany of two bloggers who published documents revealing government plans to expand surveillance has been met with resistance.
With the National Health Service struggling financially, public hospitals in Britain have been told to fill vacancies only “where essential” to save money.
Two South Korean soldiers were badly wounded in an explosion, possibly from a land mine, in the demilitarized zone dividing the two Koreas, the military said.
Two people died when a circus tent collapsed at a New Hampshire fairground during a severe storm.
An official song of the 2022 Winter Olympics in China is drawing ridicule for being suspiciously similar to “Let It Go,” the popular ballad from the Disney film "Frozen."
Without warning or explanation, the Indian government ordered Internet service providers to block access to 857 pornography websites that an activist had singled out.
London is set for another transportation disruption after a train drivers' union said it planned to go ahead with a 24-hour subway strike starting Wednesday night.
The auto industry, fresh off robust quarterly profits announced by General Motors, Ford and Fiat Chrysler, began the second half of 2015 by reporting strong sales.
The Kraft Heinz Company has recalled some of its individually wrapped cheese products over concerns that the plastic packaging could be a potential choking hazard.
Government air raids in a northwestern town in Syria and a subsequent crash by a Syrian warplane in a residential area there killed at least 27 people, activists said.
Crews in California are fighting to contain 21 wildfires. The largest of them is the Rocky Fire, above, which has burned 54,000 acres and spread to three counties in the north.
Chinese regulators have suspended more than 30 trading accounts, including one owned by the brokerage unit of the U.S. hedge fund Citadel, as they try to stabilize the markets.
The assassination in Burundi on Sunday of President Pierre Nkurunziza's former intelligence chief has led to fears of an outbreak of violence in the country.
King Salman of Saudi Arabia has left his family's mansion in France, ending an eight-day stay and a controversy over the closing of a public beach during his time there.
HSBC said its second-quarter profit fell 4 percent from a year earlier as it worked to cut up to $5 billion in annual costs by the end of 2017.
Investors issued a vote of no confidence in Greece’s economy, dumping Greek stocks as trading on the Athens stock exchange resumed for the first time in five weeks.
More than 5,300 bottles of alcohol were seized in the southern Chinese city of Liuzhou amid suspicions that distillers were putting powdered Viagra in their product.
Monsoon rains killed over 100 people in India in the past week, and tens of thousands are taking shelter in camps.
The Nigerian military said that it rescued 178 people from the Islamist militant group Boko Haram and destroyed several of the group's camps in the northeast.

display_asset.caption: A protest  Sunday in Jerusalem over an arson attack that killed a Palestinian toddler.

summaries.body: A recent firebombing, believed to be the work of Jewish extremists, has reinforced the sense that the Israeli authorities have acted with leniency toward Israeli citizens.
After its takeover of DirecTV, AT&T announced that its new offering in the United States includes high-definition and digital video recording services, wireless phone service and a data plan.
The Athens Stock Exchange is expected to fall by 20 percent when trading resumes on Monday, after being shut down for five weeks during the height of the debt crisis.

display_asset.caption: Lucas Duda hit two home runs and a double batting behind Yoenis Cespedes.

summaries.body: Lucas Duda hit two home runs and a double batting behind Yoenis Cespedes, giving the Mets a 3-2 win over the Nationals, their second dramatic win in this homestand.

posts.footer: Evan Wolfson, founder and president of New York-based Freedom to Marry, via The Washington Post

summaries.body: We’ve worked ourselves out of jobs, but the larger cause is not finished. Fighting for the same issues we always have — equality, inclusion, safety, freedom and respect.
The World Food Program announced new cuts in food aid for Syrian refugees in Jordan, highlighting a funding crisis of agencies helping millions displaced by Syria's war.
A California man who prosecutors say was a leader of an Israeli organized crime ring that moved drugs and money across the globe was sentenced to 32 years in prison.
The cybersecurity issues that led Fiat Chrysler to recall 1.4 million vehicles could be a problem for cars and trucks from other automakers, a U.S. highway safety official said.
Wages and salaries in the U.S. rose in the second quarter at the slowest pace on record, dashing projections that an improving labor market would boost pay.
Traveling at speeds of up to 240 mph, 164 skydivers flying head-down built the largest ever vertical skydiving formation over central Illinois, smashing the previous record.
The number of viewers for the first episode of E!’s “I Am Cait,” the reality series starring Cailtyn Jenner, climbed to 3.9 million, according to Nielsen data.
With four episodes of “The Daily Show” left, Jon Stewart has revealed that Amy Schumer and Louis C.K. will be among his final guests.
A court in Senegal sentenced a journalist to six months in prison for acts of homosexuality, which is illegal in the West African country.
The Coast Guard said it planned to suspend at sunset on Friday its search for two teenagers who went missing during a fishing trip off the coast of Florida last week.
A 39-year-old American woman was killed in a hotel room in Cape Town this week, and a suspect of Guatemalan origin has been arrested, the South African police said.
Uber said it would invest $1 billion in India to expand into more cities in the next six to nine months, as the ride-hailing app aims to reach one million trips daily.
Stocks in China fell modestly, but they ended July with their worst monthly decline in six years, despite government efforts to stabilize the market and prop up prices.
Japanese authorities are proceeding with criminal cases against three former Tepco executives, the first such cases to arise from the 2011 nuclear disaster.
Witnesses say a female suicide bomber has attacked a taxi rank at a crowded market in the northeastern Nigerian city of Maiduguri. At least 10 people were killed.
An Olympic torch that Bruce Jenner, now Caitlyn Jenner, carried in Lake Tahoe, Nev., before the 1984 Summer Games sold for nearly $24,000 at an auction.

posts.footer: A journalist in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, where Beijing and Almaty, Kazakhstan, were making their final presentations to the International Olympic Committee in hopes of being chosen later Friday to host the 2022 Winter Games, via Twitter

summaries.body: And the Beijing delegation is entering the room ... with Yao Ming serving as a very noticeable anchor at the back of the line.
Hundreds of students stormed Taiwan's Education Ministry, protesting what they say are plans to give high school textbooks a pro-China bias.

display_asset.caption: President Obama signed an executive order calling for the creation of the first computer able to perform a quintillion operations a second.

summaries.body: President Obama said the government would try to build the first computer capable of a quintillion operations a second, which could have transformative uses in many fields.
North Korea’s official news agency said a Canadian pastor who has been detained there since February had confessed to crimes aimed at overthrowing the country’s government.

posts.footer: Sweden’s interior minister, Anders Ygeman, who said the government would investigate how the police respond to frivolous calls from the public, via The Local

summaries.body: If you receive an ugly sweater from your mother for Christmas, you should take it up with her and not with the police.

display_asset.caption: Ai Weiwei in Munich on Thursday with his wife, Lu Qing, and son, Ai Lao.

summaries.body: The Chinese artist Ai Weiwei was denied a six-month business visa by Britain, which said he lied on his application by failing to say he had been convicted of a crime.

display_asset.caption: Rescue personnel searched for landslide victims at in the Nepalese village of Lumle on Thursday. Landslides are common in Nepal during monsoon season, which lasts from June until September.

summaries.body: Landslides set off by heavy rain struck several villages in western Nepal, killing at least 33 people, an official said.
Israeli legislators voted to allow the force-feeding of hunger-striking prisoners in extreme cases. Rights groups condemned the move.

display_asset.caption: Facebook's solar-powered drone, known as Aquila, is said to be ready for in-flight tests.

summaries.body: Facebook said its unmanned drone, intended to bring Internet access to remote areas, is ready for tests in the upper atmosphere, most likely in the United States.
A California wildfire has consumed 8,300 acres north of the Napa Valley and forced 650 people from their homes. The blaze is one of 14 raging in the drought-stricken state.

posts.footer: Giants co-owner John Mara on Jason Pierre-Paul, the team's best defensive player. He said the Giants have not seen Pierre-Paul since he was hurt in a Fourth of July fireworks accident.

summaries.body: I don’t know how many fingers he has.
The little spacecraft that landed on a comet last November has provided an intriguing wealth of data, including the discovery of complex organic molecules.
Chad said its forces had killed 117 Boko Haram insurgents during a two-week military campaign aimed at clearing islands on Lake Chad used by the militants as hideouts.
NBCUniversal is poised to make a pair of investments in the digital media start-ups BuzzFeed and Vox, seeking to appeal to younger millennial viewers, executives said.
A Sierra Leone man died from Ebola in an area where the virus had been gone for months, leading the authorities to quarantine his home village and nurses who treated him.
The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service said it is investigating the killing of Cecil the lion in Zimbabwe, but it has been unable to contact the American dentist accused of the hunt.
